name: George Herman Babcock
content:
George Herman Babcock (June 17, 1832 – December 16, 1893) was an American inventor. He and Stephen Wilcox co-invented a safer water tube steam boiler, and founded the Babcock & Wilcox boiler company.
 Babock was born in Unadilla Forks, New York in a family of inventors.[1] As a boy he started his career in the woolen mill industry. Still in his tens he started a printing office in Westerly, Rhode Island. Here he founded the Literary Echo journal, which was later renamed The Narragansett and was continued until the end of 19th century. Through his interest in photography he started a printing-press manufacture, for which he invented a polychromatic press for printing in several colors.[2]
 After moving to New York Babcock taught mechanical drawing at the Cooper Institute. He was a draughtsman for the Mystic Iron Company and the Hope Iron Company in Providence. Here with Stephen Wilcox he developed the Babcock and Wilcox engine, which was taken into production.[2] They eventually founded the Babcock & Wilcox boiler company. In 1886-1887 Babcock served as president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. 
 Babcock's water tube steam boiler provided a safer and more efficient production of steam, and was built to work better under higher pressures than earlier boilers. In 1881 their company was incorporated, with Babcock as president and Wilcox as vice president.
 He died in Plainfield, New Jersey on December 16, 1893.[3]
 In 1997, Babcock was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

raw:
American inventor (1832–1893)


George Herman BabcockBorn(1832-06-17)June 17, 1832Unadilla Forks, New YorkDiedDecember 16, 1893(1893-12-16) (aged 61)Plainfield, New JerseyOccupationEngineerEngineering careerSignificant advanceCo-inventor of an improved safety water tube boiler
Signature
George Herman Babcock (June 17, 1832 – December 16, 1893) was an American inventor. He and Stephen Wilcox co-invented a safer water tube steam boiler, and founded the Babcock & Wilcox boiler company.

Biography[edit]
Babock was born in Unadilla Forks, New York in a family of inventors.[1] As a boy he started his career in the woolen mill industry. Still in his tens he started a printing office in Westerly, Rhode Island. Here he founded the Literary Echo journal, which was later renamed The Narragansett and was continued until the end of 19th century. Through his interest in photography he started a printing-press manufacture, for which he invented a polychromatic press for printing in several colors.[2]
After moving to New York Babcock taught mechanical drawing at the Cooper Institute. He was a draughtsman for the Mystic Iron Company and the Hope Iron Company in Providence. Here with Stephen Wilcox he developed the Babcock and Wilcox engine, which was taken into production.[2] They eventually founded the Babcock & Wilcox boiler company. In 1886-1887 Babcock served as president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. 
Babcock's water tube steam boiler provided a safer and more efficient production of steam, and was built to work better under higher pressures than earlier boilers. In 1881 their company was incorporated, with Babcock as president and Wilcox as vice president.
He died in Plainfield, New Jersey on December 16, 1893.[3]
In 1997, Babcock was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

References[edit]


^ The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography. V. James T. White & Company. 1907. pp. 304–305. Retrieved March 24, 2021 – via Google Books.

^ a b "George H. Babcock; in Memoriam," in Transactions of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. v.15 1894.

^ "Inventor George H. Babcock". Chicago Tribune. Plainfield, New Jersey. December 18, 1893. p. 7. Retrieved March 24, 2021 – via Newspapers.com.
